Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned how to run significance tests and to regress variables to analyze their relationships to each other. I also learned how to interpret a number of values and graphs, depending on the context and purpose. I gained experience in using Stata to analyze large amounts of data, a necessary skill for the social sciences.
I learned basic stats for the first time. It was rather painless.
I come away from this course with a new understanding of introductory statistics, including utilizing descriptive statistics, predictive methods, and regression analysis.
Statistics
Great class - I learned how to pick up a report and understand the statistics inside to a fairly confident level
stats! yay!
This class is meant for you to learn about the basics of statistics, particularly in a social science context.
Intro stats so everything from mean, median, and mode to multiple regressions. Heavy focus on the language of stats and not so much the math side of it.
I learned basic statistical skills.
I gained a good basic understanding of stats for social sciences. There was an appropriate amount of material and work.
I learned a lot of introductory statistics! And more importantly, I learned the role of statistics in public policy considerations.
This class helped gain a better understanding of basic statistics and how researchers can use Stata to study large populations and derive meaningful information.
I learned so much about statistics in this class, but not just the formulas: the professor really gets you to understand the concepts behind them.
Learnt a lot about statistics and how to apply them to the wider world - was more interesting than other stats courses because of its practical application.
A lot about introductory statistics
Pretty comprehensive understanding of stats.
Very broad look into introductory statistics, and how they affect research analysis
It was great!
Basic stats knowledge, new way of thinking about the world
I learned not just more statistical techniques, but also the theory and conceptual backing behind them.

In this course, I gained insight into general statistical concepts. I also learned how to use STATA, a statistical software package. This class was incredibly informative and gave me a good primer into the statistical concepts necessary in the field of social science. This course covered significance tests, confidence intervals, p-values, regression models and beyond!
The basics of statistics with a social science focus.
You get an intro to statistics that is more in-depth and social sciences focused than AP Stats. However, AQA doesn't go through quite the same breadth of material.
I learned a lot about statistics by taking this course.
Good understanding of statistics and its proper application in social science

This class gives you a great undestanding of the material it covers, which is basic statistical analysis methods, particularly the ones most often used in social science research. That being said it covers very little material (less than AP Stats even) and doesnt even cover all of the most common statistical methods (e.g. ANOVA). But what you do learn, you learn well.
This is a basic intro stats class so that is the knowledge I learned.
Statistics or social science
I learned many important theories behind statistical methodologies and how to perform various types of statistical analysis by hand and through Stata, a computer program.
Solid basics of applied statistics needed for social science work, interpretative skills, the use of Stata software.

The material is overall quite simple as long as students make an effort to understand it. The lectures sometimes over-emphasized relatively unimportant concepts, which made it more difficult to see what was really important to know in statistics.

The course moves at the pace of the class, which is great. All problem sets are tailored to what we cover in lecture, and I never felt that I had to leave class with any unanswered questions. 

To be perfectly honest, statistics is generally a quite boring subject but Professor Thomas manages to make it fun and accessible.

Overall, the course is great. JT really does his absolute best to take a dry topic- statistics- and make it engaging and interesting. I think the course could be adjusted a bit- the pace seemed really slow at first and we covered the introductory material really in-depth, but then by the end of the term it seemed like we rushed through really complicated material because we had to get through it. I think there were definitely time pressures given the delay in the course's schedule, but any way to balance out the time spent on material, especially as we get into regression, would be particularly helpful.
I think sometimes the course moved too slow (took too many questions) and sometimes way too fast (some of the more complicated theory based material).
JT makes the class. He takes pretty dry material and shows the relevance. Wouldn't ask to improve the class - I got exactly what I expected out of it.
this course was well taught & well organized, but problem sets were weighted too heavily.  problem sets could better be used for feedback, rather than assessment.

The TAs could be better about teaching the material rather than just reading off of the material. There isn't much feedback on performance of the psets and it's difficult to understand what you did wrong. The availability of the TAs are not great either. However, the level of material is not clearly communicated. You must go through ALL lectures. The lectures are by far your best resource. Don't use the textbook too much especially because there are a lot of additional material that isn't relevant.

Annoying that he would post the problem sets on Thursday nights (sometimes Friday morning) and they were due on Wednesday. The answer keys for the practice exams weren't super helpful, all of them said "See lecture notes" for explanations. JT could have also gone through more examples of problems in class so that we had a better idea of how to do them.
JT is a great professor. The end of the course could be a bit better organized, and perhaps a little more applied stuff (looking at research, etc.) would be worthwhile.
This course was run very smoothly.

The strengths of this course are that the instructor is energetic, friendly, and approachable. He makes every lecture fun and makes sure to tie in the statistics into public policy, grounding the sometimes abstract and intangible concepts to applicable examples. The TFs are also very helpful and friendly.
There are no weaknesses -- this is a fantastic course.

Weakness: more past practice papers / problems before midterm and final to help grasp material more

Strengths: JT. Hes literally THE BEST.
Well taught, less focused on stata
Loved the professor.  Pace of the class was somewhat slow, felt like we learned every concept 2 or 3 times.

Strengths: Justin.Thomas.My.Man.

Weaknesses: I wish the introduction of GLBL 122 into spring semesters would've been made more clear at the beginning of this semester
JT is awesome. Course stuff can get hard at end.

Strengths: Fantastic teaching team, great TAs, collaborative learning environment, JT welcomed questions 

Weaknesses: I didn't feel that there were enough office hours to feel supported, maybe try adding Piazza as a viable tool
 For the practice midterms, when the answers say to look at the lecture notes, I know that myself and other students are generally super confused and it's difficult to find that specific information, so if maybe you could include the specific lecture or slide number that it's on would be helpful.

The course is great in that it goes in depth into each concept, but I felt it went by too slowly overall, which is the expense to be paid for making sure all students understand the material thoroughly.

This is a very strong course. Justin Thomas is an excellent instructor and a great communicator. He knows what concepts need special emphasis as well as what questions to ask the class during lecture. Justin really makes the class and knows exactly what he's doing. I feel as though I've left this class fully prepared to confront statistical information across the social sciences and how to read scientific papers with statistical information. 

While the majority of the course felt very well paced, I felt as though the end of the course felt rushed. Complex material was glossed over. This might have been due to the time lost from the snowstorm. Regardless, I would have preferred a little more clarity during lectures towards the end. 

Also, Justin is probably a little bit too nice. At times, he would answer too many questions that students had and we could remain stuck on a single topic for a very long time. Throughout most of the semester he knew when to move on and how to set a strong pace, but sometimes the class just got stuck going over the same concept due to students' repetitive questions. It's hard to ask a professor to ignore student questions, but I feel confident in saying that Justin could benefit from being a little less responsive. He was always so considerate and thoughtful which is a great quality in a professor. Unfortunately, his care for his students sometimes dragged the momentum of the class.

I'm really splitting hairs here. Other than those two notes I think this class is truly superb. Justin knows exactly what he's doing and was able to make a stats class completely accessible to this lowly English major.

The primary strength of this course was its applied nature. Learning how the concepts could relate to real-world studies was fascinating and built on the knowledge of statistics I'd developed in AP Stats during high school. However, lecture was often disorganized, as was section. While Professor Thomas is a great person, I didn't feel his lectures were effective. They were often filled with tangents, and the material could easily get confusing when he didn't stick to the slides. Often I felt I learned better by studying the slides on my own. Section had similar problems, as there was no clear organization (i.e. no power points and lacking notes). Grading was also extremely inconsistent. On the midterm, for instance, deductions for small errors often seemed arbitrary and too high. Problem sets faced the same issue. Overall, I think this class needed far more organization.
The teacher was amazing for this course. There were no weaknesses.

The course focuses on building a good base of knowledge in statistics and pays detailed attention to learning how to evaluate research methods of others; some of the introductory material could have been covered in less time to reserve more time at the end for deeper coverage of regression, etc.

Probably one of the best taught classes at Yale, everyone in class is engaged and actively learning which was highly refreshing. The stuff you learn you really learn very well. The textbook is also fantastic. The main weakness of the class is the pace. While the slow plod allows you to grasp everything excellently, we didnt cover much at all, and learned almost nothing new after spring break.

This courses pace was too slow, we spent way too much time on certain material (sampling distribution and significance tests) and not enough on others (multi-variate regression). One strength of this is that it was very clear in expectations and instructions. Problem set grading could be improved by either describing on the actual problem set what was wrong or release problem set solutions.

I thought the course was designed well overall. However, perhaps there could've been more specific guidance about incorporating our textbook pages with the lectures. Moreover, I think section can be designed a bit better. Sometimes, we moved quite quickly through difficult material. Perhaps having more structured sections where students can do practice problems would be an improvement. Also, there seemed to be inconsistent grading for the problem sets, which was frustrating. I'm not sure if the Teaching Fellows used rubrics to grade, but that might improve consistency. The answer keys to the practice exams should also be improved. Some practice questions asked students to "see lecture notes" for answers...what if our lecture notes don't have the answer, not matter how diligent we are? If the goal was to have students figure out the answers themselves, then why provide an answer key in the first place? Also, there wasn't much clear feedback on the exams. Again, a detailed answer key would've been ideal.

If you want to take a statistics course, take this one. The problem sets are for the most part straightforward and you learn all the same skills you'd learn in a standard intro stats course, but in a smaller class environment where the professor is very passionate about teaching and makes every effort to get to know students by their first names.
Yeah it was great!

Absolutely. If you want to learn statistics, this is an awesome introductory course. I didn't take stats in highschool, so I went into this course raw and did not find it too demanding. Professor Thomas is always available to answer questions after class and generally does not move on from a newly introduced topic until he has addressed all questions that students have.

If JT is teaching the course, yes, you should take this if you are looking for a challenging but not super "actual math" heavy QR course or as an alternative to Intro Stats. JT works so hard to make this course and its naturally pretty dry material engaging and relevant. I, unlike many of the folks taking the class, did not need this course for GLBL requirements, I took it because I needed a QR credit and thought it would be particularly relevant as a PLSC major. First off, let me say that this being a "math" class shouldn't scare you off. The math utilized is quite basic, really just algebra and plugging things into equations. The difficult part of the course is the theoretical components. I would definitely say that the class is a lot of work- the psets take increasing amounts of time and the midterm/final are extensive and will challenge you. In particular, I'd say the last few weeks of the course are really when everything ramps up and it can get to be a lot. The course spends a lot of time on the introductory material and it often times seems like we really rushed through difficult concepts like regression analysis. But the light of this class really is JT. I can't emphasize how great he is in making the course engaging and interesting. His teaching style is fantastic and really loves working with his students. In short, if you're looking for a QR class that will push you and looking for an incredible professor, look no further than AQA.
I would. It's a straightforward course and JT is an great teacher who is very engaging.

Not easy, but also not difficult.  JT is hilarious-- makes the lectures very enjoyable-- and his shticks keep you going through some boring material. Psets can be a pain but always straight-forward and if you go to most lectures and sections and the occasional office hours you'll do well. (Textbook readings unnecessary). Exams are both fair and ultimately you learn basic stats stuff that is actually useful - definitely worth taking.

If you're looking for a stats and don't have to take Econometrics, I would highly recommend this course. JT is an excellent professor and he gives you the basics to pick up a study and understand all the stats inside without having to spend hours going over dry proofs. I enjoyed it, and it was not very difficult.
yes--useful stuff

For most students, this class is a requirement so you have to take it. Of the global requirements, this class is slightly less painful. The level of content isn't extremely difficult but the pace does pick up. When JT tells you that the material gets harder, HEED his word. It's an ok QR credit if you already have background in statistics. But just because the first two weeks are easy doesn't mean that it's an easy class.
Yes! Stats are important and its an easy QR! Great professor, too!
For sure an interesting QR credit, and JT is a great professor.
I would recommend this class, because it gives you a good basic understanding with a lot of fun stories.

I would highly recommend this course to another student! Especially if, like me, you have never taken stats before. The teaching staff does a great job walking you through the statistics and also grounding it in applicable public policy examples.
Definitely take this course if you need to ease into QR classes. JT and the TAs offer feedback that actually helps you improve.
Absolutely. If you want to learn about statistical analysis, this is your class.

Probably not the most useful for someone in my situation, who's looking for a working understanding of statistics and a qr credit. Difficult to understand mathematical theory behind the concepts when the class only half covers it. psets are kind of fun, in the way puzzles can be, but doing calculations by hand often sucks up huge amounts of time.

I would recommend it to any student looking for a stats course that is interesting (as it has practical applications in the real world and we dealt with real life data). Moreover, JT is one of the best professors Ive ever had at Yale and made learning entertaining and worthwhile.
Yes
Yes, pretty easy, conceptually interesting, great teacher.
Sure! It is a requirement for Global, and an interesting course for Stats majors

Most students taking this class are Global majors, but as an EP&E major, this class was a great choice for me to fulfill the econometrics requirement considering I had no previous statistics experience and don't plan on needing an actual econometrics course in the future (even if you plan on taking it, this is a better intro stats choice than stats 100 in my opinion). Some of the topics are difficult to master if you aren't very quantitative/haven't taken math or stats in a while, but Professor Thomas' lectures are really great and I found section to actually be very helpful for problem sets, unlike some other classes. The curve is generous and help is readily available. Problem sets can be time-consuming but are fairly manageable. I wish this had been my only p-set class so I could have put more time into them, but I got by okay. Take it if you need it, and rest assured that this is probably the best teaching around for the subject matter.
JT is awesome.
Yes, JT, Jill, and Becca are all greta resources and want to help us succeed.

I would. The professor alone makes this course worth taking. It gives you good statistical knowledge to be an informed consumer of research, and the professor makes it as engaging as possible for a stats course.

I would absolutely recommend this course! I took this course for a QR credit and really enjoyed it. Justin Thomas is a great teacher and really knows what he's doing. I'm very happy I took this course and now feel as though I have a strong foundation in statistics. I'm also glad I learned how to use STATA.
Yes, this is one of the best QRs you can take.

This isn't a bad course per se, i.e. the material you learn is interesting and relevant. But you should be prepared to learn a lot of it on your own, as the class is organized in a way that can make the material confusing.

I would recommend this class to any humanities or social sciences majors who are looking to fulfill a QR and want to take a class that will have real-world application. It is not a gut. This is the perfect way to learn quantitative skills that will be applicable at one point in your future.
I would definitely recommend this class to another student. The teacher is awesome and you learn valuable skills

This course is required for Global Affairs majors but also provides a good introduction to statistics for people like me with no background in the subject; I now feel much more confident evaluating research papers and understanding methods used and rationale for them

Look, if you want to take a class with a good teacher and really understand the basics of how statistical analysis is possible then definitely take this class. But if youre looking to learn anything beyond t-tests and Linear Regression Models, you just wont get there in AQA. That being said, it is highly enjoyable, and Justin Thomas probably deserves a teaching award.

If you are not strong on math or theoretical understanding take this course, otherwise I would recommend taking the intro stats class in the S&DS department which is more of a challenge and you likely learn more in.

Yes, I'd definitely recommend this class to a student who wanted to focus on theory of introductory statistics. Indeed, this class was heavily based on understanding theory, which is helpful for developing a deeper understanding of statistics. The course load was manageable, but students should understand that some of the problem sets require many, many hours (sometimes upwards of 5) to complete.

Highly recommend for all social science students who think they dread stats. Prof. Thomas is an incredible instructor and knows how to convey knowledge so that non-math-y people will understand. The class is well structured, very informative, and tailored to the needs of Global Affairs, Political Science and other social science audience who needs stats as tools in research work. The workload is normal, if you go to lectures (which are great and I wholeheartedly recommend doing so) and do psets, you're fine. Problems revolve around actual interesting data and the class is overall very engaging and useful. Do it.
